predicate.note: Frames file for 'cut' based on survey of initial sentences of big corpus and comparison with 'reduce'

example.name: it slices, it dices, it makes julienne fries!
example.text: Trading companies can cut through the logjam that small-company owners often face.
example.arg: the logjam that small-company owners often face.

example.name: with source
example.text: Longer production runs would cut inefficiencies from adjusting machinery between production cycles.
example.note: I think that's the wrong syntactic parse, actually, but we'll go with it.

example.name: with EXT
example.text: Magna recently cut its quarterly divided in half.

example.name: with start and end points
example.text: Goody Products Inc cut its quarterly dividend to five cents a share from 11.5 cents a share.

example.name: but usually with just arg1
example.text: NL and Mr. Simmons cut the price they were proposing for Georgia Gulf.
example.arg: the price they were proposing for Georgia Gulf

example.name: cut into
example.text: Net cash income -- the amount left in farmers' pockets after deducting expenses from gross cash income -- increased in 33 states in 1988, as the drought cut into crop yields and drove up commodity prices, the department's Economic Research Service reported yesterday.

example.name: completely reduce
example.text: For the first time, the U.S. considered cutting Mr. Noriega from its intelligence payroll -- and the deliberations were intense, Mr. Turner says.

roleset.name: various idiomatic usages

example.name: cut class
example.text: It was full of violence and gangs and kids cutting class

example.name: cut it
example.text: Many older athletes wonder if they can still cut it.

example.name: cut corners
example.text: ``Most of us grew up [*-2] believing in the axioms `Haste makes waste' and `[*] Don't cut corners,'...

example.name: cut a deal
example.text: In addition, White House aides think that there are numerous other important measures Democrats badly wanted passed -- such as the scaling back of a controversial catastrophic health-care plan for the elderly -- that might provide the president leverage in [*] cutting deals with Democrats.
example.note: That's the way Treebank parses it, too.

roleset.note: This encompasses a wide range of senses, but they all take basically the same PAS.

example.name: detassling
example.text: The seed companies cut off the tassels of each plant.
example.note: Just for the record, I'd like to point out that it isn't the seed companies that do this detasseling, but legions of Midwestern teenagers.

example.name: overeating
example.text: ``Whoa,'' thought John, ``I've got to start cutting back on my intake of chocolate.''

example.name: now cut that out!
example.text: The move will cut out the cost of a middleman and give Specialized more control over marketing and sales.

example.name: here ya go
example.text: As the building's new owner, Chase will have its work cut out for it.
example.note: Weird; I don't think the active can occur.

roleset.name: cut loose: set or become free

example.name: ergative
example.text: Mr. Roman, by contrast, seems [*-1] rarely to cut loose at all, although he did appear at Ogilvy's Halloween party Friday decked out in duck feet and a duck hat, costumed as a ``lame duck.''
example.arg: although he did appear at Ogilvy's Halloween party Friday decked out in duck feet and a duck hat, costumed as a ``lame duck.''

example.name: PETA would be happy
example.text: An undistinguished college student who dabbled in zoology until he concluded that he couldn't stand cutting up frogs, Mr. Corry wanted to work for a big company ``that could do big things.''
